Alistair A. Israel wrote:

>  > public void testSetWidthBadValue() {
>  >      MyRectangle rect = new MyRectangle();
>  > 
>  >      try{
>  >          rect.setWidth(-5);
>  >          fail("negative widths are illegal");
>  >      }
>  >      catch(IllegalArgumentException expected)
>  >      {}
>  > }
> 
> My comments to this approach (and it seems everybody else does this,
> as seen by three nearly identical responses to the original post):
> 
> 1. Empty {} block. I dunno, I'm anal that way.

Understood, but don't let being anal be an excuse to turn your brain 
off. Never trust absolute rules.

> 2. It's easy to make the mistake of catching Exception - which will
> cause the test to pass if _any_ exception is thrown, even if it wasn't
> the one expected.

If you see this:

catch (Exception expected) {}

...might you not question whether the code /really/ expects /any/ 
exception? I would. If I didn't trust the code -- for example because I 
had no idea who wrote it -- I'd investigate a little.

The point is calling the variable 'expected', which hammers home the 
intent of the code.

Plus I don't see why anyone's more likely to type "catch (Exception 
...)" using the standard approach or your approach.
